Rajesh Jha
Rajesh Jha
postsData.content:
Built my dream house for my Mother ️ at the age of 27 

- I don't go to the pub.
- I don't drink or smoke.
- I don’t go out every weekend to party.
- I don’t binge-watch TV shows for hours on end.

Some might say I’m not enjoying life.
Others might think I don’t know how to live.
Some even say I’ll regret it if I don’t enjoy it now.

But for me, building a house with my hard-earned money and gifting it to my mother was a priority ️.

 For me, enjoyment is achieving my goals and ensuring my parents have the best life.

 For me, enjoyment is helping students with their career growth.

At the age of 13, I lost my father. Since then, my mother has been my world.
I knew I had to step up, work hard, and give her the life she deserves.

Don’t let others tell your definition of enjoyment. Everyone’s journey is unique, and your idea of joy might be different from theirs.

I wish you all bring good fortune to your families and make your parents proud.

God is great ️

How you start your Sunday often sets the tone for the rest of the week. If you wake up with intention and gratitude, you’ll carry that energy into Monday and beyond. 

Take this Sunday to reflect, reset, and recharge. Prioritize what truly matters — whether it’s taking time for self-care, planning your goals, or simply being present with loved ones.

A well-spent Sunday can help you show up as your best self throughout the week. So, ask yourself:

 What mindset am I bringing into this week?

 What actions can I take today that align with my goals?

 How can I set myself up for success, both personally and professionally?


Remember, how you spend your Sunday sets the foundation for the rest of your week.

So, let's make this Sunday count and create a positive ripple effect throughout the week!

postsData.content:
The Sunday Reset: Setting the Tone for the Week


For the longest time, Sundays felt like a weird in-between—too late to fix last week, too early to start the next.

Some weeks, I’d ignore my to-do list and convince myself I deserved an entire day of rest. Other times, I’d try to cram in everything I neglected during the week, leaving me drained before Monday even began.

Then I realized something: Sundays aren’t just for rest, and they aren’t just for productivity either. They’re for resetting.

Now, I use Sundays to reflect, plan, and recharge. I check in with myself, tidy my space, set my priorities, and do something that fuels me.

It’s not about having the ‘perfect’ routine—it’s about finding balance so I don’t enter the new week feeling behind before it even starts.

How do you spend your Sundays?

Karnamrta Krishna Dasa
Karnamrta Krishna Dasa
postsData.content:
Know that God is working behind the scenes for our good, even when what is happening on the stage doesn’t seem to be good.

A fundamental truth of spirituality is that there is much more to reality than what meets the eye. Guided by spiritual knowledge, we understand that, bigger than the visible material reality, no matter how grand it may seem, is the invisible spiritual reality. And in that spiritual realm reigns supreme the all-loving, all-attractive divinity, Krishna, the greatest well-wisher of all living beings.

We may conceptually understand God as the greatest reality in terms of the structure of things, yet we often forget that this truth applies not only to the structure but also to the workings of things. God is not a distant being, content in his supremacy and unconcerned with what happens elsewhere. Instead, he is active, working behind the scenes, moving the world and all living beings toward ultimate auspiciousness. As the Bhagavad-gita (9.10) declares, the Lord oversees the movements of material nature.

postsData.content:
My Mentor’s $100 test left me speechless, and it might change how you see yourself forever

She pulled out a crisp $100 bill and asked:
"Do you want this?"
Of course, I said yes.

Then she crumpled it up.
"Still want it?"
Yes.

Then she threw it on the floor, stomped on it, and picked it up again.
"Still want it?"
Obviously.

Then she looked me straight in the eye and said something that shook me to my core:

“Then why do you let failure, rejection, or someone’s opinion make you forget your worth?”

That moment was a wake-up call.
Read this twice:

- A rejection email doesn’t erase your talent.
- A bad day doesn’t define your future.
- No one (not a boss, a client, or a stranger) gets to decide your worth.

Life will stomp on you. People will doubt you.
But none of that changes who you are.
Stand tall. Move forward. Own your worth!

PS: If you had to give one piece of advice to someone struggling with self-doubt right now, what would it be?

postsData.content:
Hangman Game with Python & Tkinter 
I recently developed a simple yet fun Hangman Game using Python and Tkinter for the graphical user interface. This game allows users to guess a randomly selected word letter by letter. With a visually appealing design and interactive gameplay, it’s a great way to practice coding while enjoying a classic word-guessing game.

Key Features:
1) Random Word Selection: Picks a random word from a predefined list.
2) Dynamic Display: Shows underscores for unguessed letters, and updates in real-time as the player makes correct guesses.
3) Guess Tracking: Keeps track of guessed letters, with a limit on the number of incorrect guesses.
4) Message Alerts: Provides feedback on each guess (correct, incorrect, or already guessed).
5) Interactive UI: Built with Tkinter, featuring an intuitive layout with an input field for user guesses, chances left, and real-time game messages.
Game Reset: Includes a button to restart the game once it's over.

Tools Used:
1) Python
2) Tkinter (GUI)

This project not only helped me improve my skills with Python but also gave me a deeper understanding of game logic, user interaction, and GUI design.
And I would like to thank my mentor Gaurav sir for helping me and giving me a proper guidance on this project
Thank You
,

John Brewton
John Brewton
postsData.content:
Failure is not the enemy.
It’s the entrance fee.

Some people fear failure.
Others avoid it.
The smartest among us use it to their massive advantage.
The real test isn’t whether you fail, it’s whether you develop the skills to succeed because of it.

Over the years, I’ve noticed that those who can overcome any failure tend to have 9 key traits:
1️⃣ They learn from anyone.
↳ They don’t let ego block insight and seek wisdom from every experience.
2️⃣ They’re relentlessly curious.
↳ They ask “why?” constantly, knowing great answers come from better questions.
3️⃣ They question the status quo.
↳ They challenge norms, think differently, and refuse to follow blindly.
4️⃣ They embrace being wrong.
↳ They see failure as an upgrade, not a setback, and adjust quickly.
5️⃣ They find joy in learning.
↳ Learning fuels them, keeping them engaged and moving forward.
6️⃣ They know they don’t know everything.
↳ The more they learn, the more they realize how much they don’t know.
7️⃣ They look for diverse perspectives.
↳ They surround themselves with thinkers who challenge and refine their views.
8️⃣ They push their limits.
↳ They play the long game, knowing setbacks are steps, not stops.
9️⃣ They ask the right questions.
↳ They know the right question unlocks the next breakthrough.

Somewhere along the way,
we got it backward.

We started believing
that those with the most success
have the least amount of failure.

But it’s the people who fail the most,
and build the capacity to learn
the most from these trials,
that write the greatest
success stories.

So if you’ve been failing, good.
Keep going.
You’re closer than you think.

How do you use failure to propel you forward?
How do you learn best from failure?
Drop a comment below with your hard won perspective?

______

 Follow me,, for content that Helps ().
️ Repost to your networks, colleagues, and friends if you think this would help them.

Test-time scaling flips the AI optimization paradigm. Models aren't computation-bound—they're exploration-constrained. Force deeper traversal of solution space and performance jumps 27% on MATH/AIME24.

Budget forcing isn't a hack—it's thermodynamic control. Each "Wait" token drives the system into lower-entropy states, revealing a fundamental link between compute time and reasoning depth.

The s1K dataset shatters conventional wisdom. Strong reasoning doesn't need massive data—it needs precise sampling of the difficulty-diversity manifold. They found the minimal basis set for cognitive emergence.

This isn't about math problems. They discovered direct control over reasoning depth in neural architectures. Every cognitive task follows these same optimization principles.

Intelligence isn't fixed at training—it's dynamically controllable through compute-time manipulation.

Kiran Babu
postsData.content:
Imagine walking into work one day and sensing an eerie quietness—fewer colleagues in meetings, budgets tightening, and whispered conversations behind closed doors. Are these signs of layoff?

Layoffs are unsettling but often predictable if you know where to look.

Companies facing financial struggles or strategic shifts exhibit clear warning signs long before pink slips arrive.


Here are a few red flags that you need to look out for

1. Hiring and Spending Freezes: The First Alarm Bell
When a company stops hiring or freezes discretionary spending (delay major investments), it signals financial uncertainty or a shift in priorities.

This preventive approach allows companies to control costs without immediately resorting to layoffs. However, if the situation worsens, a hiring freeze is often the precursor to more drastic cuts.


2. Executive Departures and Internal Restructuring
When key executives exit or teams undergo sudden reorganization, it often signals instability, internal disagreements about the company’s direction and impending workforce reductions.

Simultaneously, restructuring efforts designed to “streamline operations” may disguise downsizing efforts.

Executive changes often precede layoffs, as new leadership may implement cost-cutting strategies that impact headcount.

If leadership changes and restructuring weren’t enough, employees should pay special attention to company-wide meetings that appear out of nowhere.


3. The Dreaded Company-Wide Meeting: An Ominous Sign
An unexpected, urgent all-hands meeting often precedes major announcements—frequently layoffs or restructuring plans.

History has shown that sudden company-wide meetings, especially those led by top executives, rarely bring good news. Employees are often briefed on “new directions,” “tough decisions,” or “necessary adjustments”—all coded language for impending job losses.

These meetings usually serve as the final step before layoffs are announced, confirming suspicions raised by hiring freezes, executive departures, and restructuring. If such a meeting is scheduled, employees should prepare their résumés and explore contingency plans.


Understanding these signals can help employees act proactively rather than being caught off guard when layoffs become a reality.While layoffs may seem sudden, they are often preceded by unmistakable warning signs.

Employees should remain alert to hiring and spending freezes, executive exits, internal restructuring, and unexpected company-wide meetings. Each of these signals offers an opportunity to prepare, whether through upskilling, job searching, or networking.

Rather than waiting for bad news, professionals should stay vigilant, read between the lines, and take control of their career trajectory before layoffs become a reality.

comments.commentText: Interesting breakdown of warning signs, never thought about some of these before

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Staying alert to these red flags can empower employees to navigate uncertain times with confidence and proactive planning.

postsData.content:
Stay Safe on LinkedIn with These Smart Tips 

LinkedIn is a powerful platform for networking and career growth, but it’s important to protect your professional identity.

Use these tips to stay secure while making the most of your LinkedIn experience!

 Tip 1: Customize Your Profile Visibility
Control who can see your connections, activity, and contact information. Adjust your privacy settings so only trusted individuals can access sensitive details. For example, limit profile visibility to “Connections Only” for added security.

 Tip 2: Be Selective with Endorsements and Recommendations
Only accept endorsements and recommendations from people you’ve worked with directly. This ensures your profile remains credible and avoids association with potentially fake or untrustworthy accounts.

 Tip 3: Verify Job Offers and Recruiters
Before responding to job offers or recruiter messages, research the company and individual. Check their LinkedIn activity, shared connections, and online presence to confirm legitimacy. Scammers often pose as recruiters to collect personal information.

 Tip 4: Avoid Sharing Sensitive Work Details
Refrain from posting confidential company information, project specifics, or proprietary data on your profile or in updates. This protects both your employer and your professional reputation.

 Tip 5: Regularly Audit Your Connections
Periodically review your LinkedIn connections and remove any that seem suspicious or irrelevant. Keeping a curated network helps maintain the quality of your professional relationships.

 Tip 6: Monitor Login Activity
Use LinkedIn’s tools to check recent login activity on your account. If you notice logins from unfamiliar locations or devices, update your password immediately and enable two-factor authentication (2FA).

 Tip 7: Be Wary of Suspicious Messages
If someone sends you a message asking for personal information or offering unrealistic opportunities, proceed with caution. Avoid clicking on links or downloading attachments unless you’re confident they’re safe.

 Tip 8: Stay Updated on Security Practices
Regularly review LinkedIn’s security resources to stay informed about new features or potential threats. Being proactive about learning best practices keeps you one step ahead of cyber risks.

 Tip 9: Limit Third-Party App Access
Check which apps are connected to your LinkedIn account and revoke access for any that are unnecessary or unfamiliar. This reduces the risk of unauthorized data sharing.

 Tip 10: Report Suspicious Profiles or Activity
If you encounter fake profiles, phishing attempts, or inappropriate behavior, report them to LinkedIn immediately. Your actions can help protect others in the community from similar risks.

 Share this post to help others protect their LinkedIn profiles and professional identity!

postsData.content:
Something humbled me this week. I don't know if it will have the same effect on you but I'll let you decide.


As we embarked into our daily journey into the Word, I found myself explaining Psalm 3:3 to my children.


For thou, oh Lord, art a shield for me. You are my glory and the lifter of my head. 


Imagine me having to explain that David wrote this when he was running away from his son Absalom who was trying to kill him and take the throne - talk about wahala pro max...


But that not the humbling part. This is 


Imagine a soldier without a shield in the heat of the battle  That soldier is going to be hit soon!


A shield is a protective gear in warfare. David said that's who God is to him.


Unlike every other gear, a shield (and a sword) are two gears you have to be intentional in carrying and positioning.


Sometimes, the shield looks like a burden that many soldiers abandon it in the heat of battle. Some soldiers, Like Goliath of Gath, even employ others to carry it for them - remember how he ended up.


 This week, will you be intentional about putting God in His position in your life?


 Are you so busy in the midst of the battle that you have placed your shield aside and you are now fighting bare chested? This is where many Christian are. They believe God, they profess love but their hearts are far from him!


 Have you employed others to carry your shield for you - Relying on only the Sunday sermon and content creators to feed you - but no real personal and consistent relationship with God?


PS: Before I go, let me take it a notch deeper. This shield is our faith with which we quench the fiery darts of the devil.


Our faith is noth just a general idea of the existence of God. Rather, it is the position of our heart in the relevance of God as tackle our daily situations.


When you really believe that He exists and His word is true and infallible, you express it in the way you tackle doubts, fear, worry, challenges etc. Do you allow these darts penetrate or do you use your shield?


It is also evident in how you treat your successes. It's sometimes easy to turn to God in the midst of challenges and forget all about Him when things run smoothly Selah.


PS: Did you learn something? Share with me in comments.

==============================


Is knowing more about God and your purpose here on earth a priority for you in 2025?


Join me @and I will hold your hands as you grow in your knowledge of God.

postsData.content:
There’s nothing more exhausting than moving against your season.

- A flower that blooms in winter will wither.
- A river that resists its course becomes a flood.
- And a person who misreads their timing invites unnecessary battles chasing what isn’t ready or clinging to what should be released.

Life moves in seasons.
 Some are planting but quit before the roots take hold.
 Some are ready for harvest but hesitate out of fear.
 Others are in a refining storm, trying to escape when growth is found in endurance.
 Then there are those in a season of release yet they hold on, unaware that what they refuse to let go of is weighing them down.

- Discernment is what you need.

Timing is everything. A wave caught at the right moment carries you forward; a wave resisted will pull you under therefore you need to:
- Pause
- Reflect
- Align
Are you moving with your season or fighting against it?

Happy Sunday Everyone!

postsData.content:
PLM Has Failed to Deliver on Product Data—What’s Next?

For decades, PLM promised to manage and deliver product data, but the reality has fallen short. Organizations still struggle with fragmented, inaccessible information, making digital continuity a challenge. The technological shift to a Product Knowledge Graph changes the game—bringing a new paradigm for structuring, linking, and leveraging product data across the enterprise.

 Why PLM Has Failed on Product Data:
 Data silos: PLM systems lock data inside rigid structures, making integration difficult.
 Poor accessibility: Engineering, manufacturing, and supply chain teams struggle to access the right data when they need it.
 Complexity overload: Monolithic PLM implementations become bloated, costly, and hard to maintain.
 Lack of flexibility: PLM struggles to adapt to modern data models, digital threads, and AI-driven insights.
 Disconnected workflows: PLM often fails to bridge the gap between design, procurement, and production.

The Product Knowledge Graph offers a new paradigm—structuring, linking, and leveraging product data across the enterprise for better decision-making and efficiency.

How can your organization finally get the product data it needs?

Read more:  Helping Your Organization Get Product Data [link in the comment]

postsData.name:
Michael Beck
Michael Beck
postsData.content:
Incky is coming to life!

You ever get a pet and just know its name before you even meet it? Like, “I’m getting a dog, and his name is going to be Bob.” Boom. Bob. No negotiation. The dog could be a prissy little Pomeranian or a deranged mutt with an eye patch and a questionable past, but no matter what, Bob it is.

I’m not that person.

No, when I get a new pet, there’s an awkward period of name limbo. I watch them. I take note. Is this a “Mittens” situation, or am I dealing with a “Captain Poops-A-Lot”? These things require observation. Because until I know who they are, I can’t possibly know what to call them.

Turns out, building a business—our business—is a lot like that. We started with a vague sense of mission, a dream, and a logo ripped straight from the digital ether. Like a newborn cryptid, our brand was a little squishy, a little undefined, a little we’ll-figure-it-out-as-we-go.

And then, Incky happened.

At first, he was just a placeholder. A robot doodle pulled from Canva that looked suspiciously like a PlayStation mascot who might sue us in a dark alley. But when&designed our logo—oh man, that was the moment.

That was the lightning-strikes-the-monster moment.

Incky became.

A digital being who could inhabit any device, appear on any screen, traverse the wild and weird world of tech with boundless curiosity. Joyful in discovery. Solving puzzles like a tiny, heroic cyber-sleuth. A little guy, an underdog, but let’s be clear—he may be small, but he is f*cking fierce.

And that?

That’s us.

That’s.

Working in early days startups >> Working in an MNC 

Early 20s are for exploration, adaptation and evolution of an individual as a whole

Here are my cents to it
️While working with a big 4- in my first job, my role was limited to the position I was working
️MNCs have a fixed way and style of working pre defined and all members of the team follows the same. Hence no scope of bringing your uniqueness
️It can be done remotely and provides work life balance.


While working in startup is different
️Here because your role is not limited so you get to see, explore, try different things out and see for yourself what works for you or what not!
️Roles and procedures are built mid way so every individual contributes in their own individual manner
️As a lot of brainstorming is involved you work closely in office and hence learning from experienced person and building connections personally. Hence limited scope of wfh.

You get to work with leaders, take their suggestions, implement and evolve

Everyone has their own take here. What’s yours?

postsData.content:
If you’re using AI to write your LinkedIn posts—you’re making a huge mistake.

Yes it’s easier… and faster, and gets you engagement—for now.

Take a look. Scroll through your feed on any given day and >50% of the posts are AI-generated.

They all sound and look the same. The format and spacing is identical, the sentence structures are similar, with emoji placements in the same places. It’s pretty obvious.

The biggest mistake you can make is to try and build a personal brand with AI generated content. It will have the opposite effect—you’ll commoditize yourself.

What to do instead: Use AI to do research, come up with ideas, and refine your work, but write in your raw, authentic voice.

comments.commentText:
Agree with your take on LinkedIn monoculture; disagree that this is 100% because of AI.

I think the identical look of LI posts is more a function of the algorithm. As platforms mature and algorithm becomes known, people optimise for it. Posts start looking similar.

Because LinkedIn is text-first, this is more obvious than video platforms (where formatting patterns are harder to spot).

You can input into AI whatever format you want. AI lowers barrier to generate posts sure, but it's not the root cause.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Authenticity is key in building a personal brand. Let AI assist, but let your unique voice shine through! 🌟

postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM – Part 5 – CURATING Agentic Expertise
Multidisciplinary expertise is critical to correctly define the key premises driving problem analysis and solution architecture, and the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem (left image) enables capturing that expertise as a reusable computing asset.

The current AI chaos is due to 70 years of narrow and unexamined premises. The promise of AGI in the 1950s was rooted in premises that have been disproven by real-world evidence but blindly adhered to by those making today’s AGI claims. Key examples:

-Premise: language is the source of intelligence
-Reality: intelligence is the source of language - babies are intelligent before they can speak

-Premise: data is a representation of the real world
-Reality: data is the output of a machine and represents only what the machine was designed to capture

-Premise: the brain constructs objects by identifying frequent patterns of object bits
-Reality: the brain contains networks of abstract concept cells which fire when the concepts are presented in diverse versions and formats (text, image, sound, etc.)

-Premise: neural networks imitate how the brain reasons by processing massive data exhaustively
-Reality: the brain computes the relevance of inputs using inhibition networks, filtering out over 99.99% of sensory data

There are more, but the point is that the main objectives of curation are:
1-Ensure that knowledge from all relevant domains is included in the ontology
2-Map the relevant knowledge concepts across the domains to problem and solution concepts
3-Maintain the landscape concepts (science, business, regulation, etc.) reasonably updated

To enable these objectives, the custodian systems must support:
1-Biomimetic digital twinning of problem and solution concepts
2-Independent update by authorized experts
2-Simulation and testing of the impact of proposed updates across the ontology architecture

The methodology and technology to build this type of biomimetic digital twin ecosystem exist, we have produced published results, and I have discussed this in my posts.

The vision of the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem in the image, however, is in early stages and will require committed partners with the necessary resources who want to participate in shaping the implementation of this new paradigm.
postsData.commentAdded: Insightful perspective! Embracing multidisciplinary expertise is crucial for advancing AGI. Excited to see where this journey leads! #Innovation

𝗔𝗪𝗦 𝗦𝗘𝗦( Simple Email Service): 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗚𝗮𝘁𝗲𝘄𝗮𝘆 𝘁𝗼 𝗣𝗼𝘄𝗲𝗿𝗳𝘂𝗹 𝗘𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗹 𝗖𝗼𝗺𝗺𝘂𝗻𝗶𝗰𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻  
=========================================

In the era of digital communication, AWS Simple Email Service (SES) stands out as a reliable and scalable solution for email sending and receiving. Whether you're looking to send transactional emails, marketing messages, or notifications, AWS SES has you covered. Let's dive into why AWS SES is a cornerstone for effective email communication.

𝗞𝗲𝘆 𝗕𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗳𝗶𝘁𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝗔𝗪𝗦 𝗦𝗘𝗦
===================
️ 𝗖𝗼𝘀𝘁-𝗘𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲: AWS SES operates on a pay-as-you-go model, making it a highly cost-effective solution. There are no upfront costs or minimum fees, allowing businesses of all sizes to leverage its powerful capabilities without breaking the bank.

️ 𝗦𝗰𝗮𝗹𝗮𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆: AWS SES scales effortlessly to handle large volumes of emails, ensuring reliable and timely delivery. Whether you're sending a handful of emails or millions, AWS SES adjusts to meet your needs.

️ 𝗛𝗶𝗴𝗵 𝗗𝗲𝗹𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆: AWS SES boasts high deliverability rates, thanks to its robust infrastructure and advanced features like email authentication, content filtering, and reputation management. This ensures that your emails reach their intended recipients' inboxes.

️ 𝗘𝗮𝘀𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗜𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗴𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻: AWS SES integrates seamlessly with other AWS services such as S3, Lambda, and CloudWatch, as well as third-party applications. This allows you to build comprehensive email workflows and automate processes with ease.

𝗞𝗲𝘆 𝗙𝗲𝗮𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝗔𝗪𝗦 𝗦𝗘𝗦
====================
◀️ 𝗙𝗹𝗲𝘅𝗶𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗦𝗲𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗢𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀: AWS SES supports multiple email sending options, including SMTP, API, and the AWS Management Console. This flexibility allows you to choose the method that best suits your needs.

◀️ 𝗘𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗹 𝗥𝗲𝗰𝗲𝗶𝘃𝗶𝗻𝗴: AWS SES not only supports sending emails but also provides email receiving capabilities. This enables you to process incoming emails, store them in S3, and trigger Lambda functions for automated workflows.

◀️ 𝗕𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗖𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗮𝗶𝗻𝘁 𝗠𝗮𝗻𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁: AWS SES handles bounces and complaints automatically, providing detailed reports and metrics to help you maintain a healthy sender reputation.

◀️ 𝗘𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗹 𝗧𝗲𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗮𝘁𝗲𝘀: AWS SES allows you to create and manage email templates, making it easy to send personalized and consistent emails at scale.

◀️ 𝗗𝗲𝗱𝗶𝗰𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗱 𝗜𝗣 𝗔𝗱𝗱𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗲𝘀: For businesses that require higher deliverability and control over their sending reputation, AWS SES offers dedicated IP addresses.

𝗨𝘀𝗲 𝗖𝗮𝘀𝗲𝘀
=========
️ 𝗧𝗿𝗮𝗻𝘀𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹 𝗘𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗹𝘀

️ 𝗠𝗮𝗿𝗸𝗲𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗖𝗮𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗶𝗴𝗻𝘀

 𝗔𝘂𝘁𝗼𝗺𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗱 𝗪𝗼𝗿𝗸𝗳𝗹𝗼𝘄𝘀

postsData.content:
There’s a leadership lesson hiding in my son’s castle bed.

(It’s not about climbing ladders.)

My 8-year-old screams for rescue from his ‘castle bed’ every morning.
Now we conquer dragons and pancake batter instead.

Here’s the mindset shift that rewrote our routine…

For months, my son’s top-floor bunk was a daily crisis zone.
Saturday 6:30 AM: “PAPÀÀÀ!!”
I’d groan, get myself up the ladder, and start the day drained.

Then I realized: How we start our mornings affects how we show up for everything else.

How to change that?
Instead of treating it as a chore, we turned it into a ritual.

Now, when he calls, I shout back: “Coming! Do you choose to start with an adventure or breakfast today?”

Some days, we read about how Sinner has become a great tennis player.
Others, we raid the kitchen to make pancakes for the family.

The coaching lesson hiding in our castle chaos:
Resistance often comes from unmet needs, not defiance.

He doesn’t need help climbing down.
He needs connection before the day swept us apart.

3 mindset shifts that transformed our mornings (and my leadership):

1️⃣ Think about “demands” as invitations
“He’s depending on me again” becomes “He’s trusting me with his first moments.”

2️⃣ Stop being efficient, be present
Instead of rushing through the morning, we slow down to connect. A five-minute conversation beats five extra minutes of sleep any day.

3️⃣ Let them express themselves
His pancakes may look like a burnt snowman. We high-five it anyway.

1. Ask: “What’s the ‘castle bed’ moment I’ve been resisting?”

Tito Bohrt 🧪🧫 - Sales Mad Scientist
postsData.content:
Sam Altman just made a big mistake. He built an AI SDR. 



It’s not that the technology piece won’t work… it will.

The limitation of building an AI SDR is the psychology of the prospect, not the technology of the sender.

Remember when Hi {{first_name}} skyrocketed open rate from 35% to over 70%!?

You know what the effect is of {{first_name}} today? Negligible.

The same applies to job changes, and fundraising. Those strategies are dying! Why?

Because the first people who did it, it was unique, it was cool! Made the prospect feel good!

Now you change jobs and 163 companies email you about it.

Now you raise funds and 2849 companies email you about it.

The prospect simply thinks “this is so annoying”

Replies might stay high, but they’re more like “no thanks” and “go away” than “impressive email, let’s chat”

Now think about it. Sam Altman created the newest AI SDR, adoption to the moon!

It’ll likely do the above strategies and more. It means all prospects will now be more quickly annoyed even at VERY PERSONALIZED things.

Email is DEAD, mostly because AI SDRs can’t make phone calls.

Whatever Sam Altman can automate, it will desensitize in the market.

It’s a hamster wheel, not a race to a finish line. You can run faster and you’re ahead, but just for a bit before the wheel is now turning faster too.

The only way to win with Executives and Leaders is to do what the AI can’t do.

Now stop here…. Think for a second, and test out the AI SDR… then go do all the things that it can’t do. That’s where your competitive advantage lies.

Have fun!

postsData.content:
AI agent for today: automatically writes LinkedIn posts in my voice based on analyzing my last 50 posts.

This one was requested by u/Curious_Irish on Reddit, so I wanted to see how quickly I could build it and whether it would work. The answer: about 10 minutes and yes.

Here's how it works:

The agent analyzes my past LinkedIn posts with high engagement to learn my writing style, topics, and patterns. It looks at things like:
- Post structure and formatting
- Common phrases and language
- Topics that resonate with my audience
- What drives comments and reactions

Then when I give it a content idea, it drafts a post that matches my natural writing voice while incorporating what's worked well for me historically.

Let me know if you're interested in checking it out and I'll make a quick template and demo video.

p.s. other than the intro, this post was written (with very light editing) by this AI agent

Edit: there's a bit of a fun debate going on in the comments:
- Most people think this is a cool idea and want to try it
- A few think this is some combination of evil and lazy

Here's how I think about it:

From my POV, AI-assisted writing is pretty similar to something we've all done for many years:
- we have an idea
- we give the idea to someone on our team or a contractor to create a first draft
- we take that draft and edit it until it we're happy with it

If the initial idea and the final presentation aren't human and compelling, then the outcome will be the AI slop we've all seen. But if they are, you can get to high quality output way faster :)

We all just now have the luxury of a teammate that's really good and really fast!

postsData.content:
I’ve helped 100+ CEOs and entrepreneurs turn LinkedIn into a lead-gen machine.

Most struggle with low engagement & zero conversions.

To avoid this trap, here's my 5-step roadmap on how to network effectively and turn LinkedIn into a revenue machine:

𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟭: Stop Scattering Your Energy
Most people think: “I need to connect with everyone to grow.”

That’s a mistake.

To achieve real networking success:

• Define your ideal connection – Who do you need to know? Who needs your expertise?
• Prioritize decision-makers – Don’t just connect with peers; go after buyers.
• Engage with top voices in your industry – This gets you seen by their audience.

 Start here and avoid wasting time on random connections.

𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟮: Don’t Stop at 50 Requests—It’s a Numbers Game
Now you have two options:

• Send a few requests and wait for magic to happen
• Go big, track responses, and refine your outreach

There’s no wrong answer, but if you’re serious about growing, you need volume + strategy.

 100+ connection requests per week
 30%+ acceptance rate = you’re on the right track
 Keep tweaking your message for better results

Networking is a game of persistence.

𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟯: Connect, But Go Beyond 'Thanks for Connecting'
Focus on two core pillars:

1. Your First Message Matters
• Skip generic intros—lead with value
• Ask an engaging question to spark a real convo
• Find common ground fast (industry, mutual interests)

Once you master this, focus on:

2. The Follow-Up Formula
• 80% of deals come AFTER the 3rd+ follow-up
• Keep it casual but intentional (not salesy)
• Offer useful insights, not just “Hey, checking in”

Most people stop at one message. You shouldn’t.

𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟰: Build Social Proof While You Network
Mistake: Talking about yourself too much.

Easy fix: Use content to back up your credibility while you network.

Here’s how:

• Post insights from your conversations (without naming names)
• Share behind-the-scenes of working with clients
• Showcase what you’re learning + how it helps others

Your profile should do the selling for you.

𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟱: Make LinkedIn Work for You 24/7

This final step is how you:

• Turn cold outreach into warm inbound leads
• Position yourself as an authority
• Build relationships that lead to high-value opportunities

 Want more deep-dive insights on LinkedIn networking & lead-gen?

I’m sharing exclusive strategies in my newsletter today. Get it here

postsData.content:
When a prospect says they are surprised by how expensive your product is, consider this response:

“I’m surprised that you are surprised, and worry that I haven’t done a good job tying our solution to the value we see for your business.

Before we go into that, though - when you say it’s expensive, it’s expensive compared to what?”

“This is way too expensive” can mean a lot:

- It’s more than they budgeted
- It’s more than the competitor they know won’t work
- It’s fine, but they think they can get a better deal if you get nervous

Don’t panic with, “Let me talk to my manager, I’m sure we can do something for you if you sign by end of quarter.”

Do take time to understand the objection, take the conversation back to value, and find a mutually beneficial path forward.

comments.commentText:
Understanding the root cause of the objection Kyle Asay is critical. You skip this and jump to auto-discounting in a desperate attempt to close and it is a recipe for disaster especially if you cannot subsequently find out what your prospects budget is - you basically end up:

a) massively undercutting yourself in the process without realising (which is why we ask for the budget at the front end along with a bunch of other questions regarding when you do you need the physical product by etc. etc.) Ie. you clinch the deal at £20k when in reality due to the critical nature of the product you could have bagged say £40-50k (engineering is different to tech. but same principles apply here).

b) Wasting precious time for all parties with no clear target / end result as even with further discounting your prospect has already decided to proceed with a competitor but will gladly use your discount to negotiate down the other party. In any case no deal and you lost time!

c) Fixating on the wrong thing. Price is price but maybe you have to switch things up and look at alternative ways to proceed.

BOSS move: If not right having discussed it further then agree to walk away as it's not achievable right now but you keep tabs - huge respect!
thanks for adding this level of detail, James!

Kyle Asay You're welcome Kyle - always happy to bridge the gap between technical engineering sales and tech sales as there are a ton of similarities albeit I can't demo so to speak so have to rely on them having seen the type of product before and / or creating and explaining the ROI over a longer timeframe as opposed to a budget tied to a snapshot in time.
Yes, and try this too: “Seems like price is your only concern.” Pause. “Sounds like you’re comparing this to something you have or have seen.” Pause.
thanks for adding, Josh!

postsData.content:
A firestorm of debate has ignited in India since I walked off a podcast due to the poor air quality.

When in India, I ended a podcast early due to the bad air quality. Nikhil Kamathcio was a gracious host and we were having a great time. The problem was that the room we were in circulated outside air which made the air purifier I'd brought with me ineffective.

Inside, the AQI was 130 and PM2.5 was 75 µg/m³, which is equal to smoking 3.4 cigarettes for 24 hours of exposure.

This was my third day in India and the air pollution had made my skin break out in rash and my eyes and throat burn.

Air pollution has been so normalized in India that no one even notices anymore despite the science of its negative effects being well known. People would be outside running. Babies and small children exposed from birth. No one wore a mask which can significantly decrease exposure. It was so confusing.

The evidence shows that India would improve the health of its population more by cleaning up air quality than by curing all cancers.

I am unsure why India's leaders do not make air quality a national emergency. I don't know what interests, money and power keep things the way they are but it's really bad for the entire country.

When I returned to the U.S., my eyes were fresh to see what is normalized to me. I saw obesity everywhere. 42.4% of American are obese and because I was around it all the time, I had been mostly oblivious to it.

In many contexts, obesity is worse than air pollution in the long term.

Why wouldn't American leaders declare a national emergency on obesity? What interests, money and power keep things the way they are but are really bad for the entire country.

postsData.content:
The Untapped Power of "I Don't Know"
We live in a world that glorifies having all the answers. From job interviews to casual conversations, there's often pressure to appear knowledgeable and competent. But what if I told you that one of the most powerful phrases you can use is "I don't know"?
Think about it. Admitting you don't know something isn't a sign of weakness; it's a sign of strength. It demonstrates:
Humility: Acknowledging the limits of your knowledge shows self-awareness and a willingness to learn. It makes you more approachable and relatable.
Openness to Learning: Saying "I don't know" opens the door to discovery. It invites others to share their expertise, creating opportunities for collaboration and growth.
Honesty and Integrity: It's far more damaging to pretend you know something when you don't. Honesty builds trust, and trust is essential in any relationship, personal or professional.
Opportunity for Growth: "I don't know" is the first step on the path to learning. It prompts you to seek out information, ask questions, and expand your understanding.
So, the next time you're faced with a question you can't answer, don't be afraid to say those three little words. You might be surprised at the positive impact they have. Embrace the unknown, and watch your knowledge and confidence grow.
What are your thoughts on this? Share your experiences in the comments!
postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! Embracing I dont know fosters collaboration and growth. Its a powerful tool for continuous learning in todays fast-paced world!
